Getting Started

If our people fail to act with integrity, the consequences for the firm are potentially very severe. It can affect our reputation.It can affect our relationship with our clients It can affect our relationship with our regulators. And in some cases, it can have very profound consequences either for lawsuits or other enforcement actions brought againt the firm. Understanding the risks associated with bribery and corruption and ensuring that issue get excalated are important responsibilities we are all share.
-Kathryn Ruemmler, Chief legal officer and General Counsel

What are bribery and corruption?
Select each button for definitions of bribery and corruption and their relevant laws.

Bribery involves improperly offering,paying, authorizing, promising, soliciting, or receiving anything of value with the intent to obtain or retain the business, any business advantage or to influence a government or regulatory action. Bribery can involve corrupt payments to public officials, employees of corporate clients or suppliers and their relatives, agents and other private parties.
Bribery

text.default: Five Key Areas
The five main areas of heightened bribery and corruption risk are:
1. Intermediaries/Finders
2. Vendors and Other Third Parties
3. Relationship Candidates
4. Gifts, Travel and Entertainment
5. Political and Charitable Contributions
As you learn about each of these areas, pay careful attention to the red flags and sample situations where the heightened risk may not be so obvious.
You will be required to pass an assessment on these topics at the end of the module.
Learning Objectives
At the end of this training you will be able to:
Recognize key concepts related to bribery and corruption.
Identify the five main areas of heightened bribery and corruption risk
Explain the rules and requirements around each area of heightened bribery and corruption risk
Identify red flags of potential bribery and corruption and recognize when and how to escalate.
Let's check in again at the end of this training to see how comfortable you are with the five heightened areas of bribery risk and if we have achieved our learning objectives.

approximately 90% of all bribery enforcement actions have involved intermediaries/finders

What do you know about intermediaries?.

Intermediaries, regardless of whether they are directly or indirectly engaged or compensated by the firm or other parties, pose heightened riskd to the firm due to their authority to act on behalf of the firm or in association with firm business and the nature of their activites, particularly as we have limited visiblity into and control over their actions.
Why do intermediaries pose heightened risk?

text.default: Intermediaries, regardless of whether they are directly or indirectly engaged or compensated by the firm or other parties, pose heightened risk to the firm due to their authority to act on behalf of the firm or in association with firm business and the nature of their activities, particularly as we have limited visibility into and control over their actions.
What do i need to do if i am aware of intermediary involvement in a business oppurtunity?
Direct and Indirect Intermediaries
Let's break down the difference between direct and indirect intermediaries.
Select each button to learn more.

Government Entity: Refers to any office, agency, ministry, instrumentality, soveriegn wealth fund, or other part of a national, regional or local government, public international organization, or royal family.

Direct Intermediaries: Third parties engaged and/or compensated by the firm to: find, introduce identify source maintain business opportunities; interact with or introduce the firm to public officials or government officials (Review to advance) related to a business opportunity; or satisfy a condition or requirement of a client public official or government entity in the firm involvement of a business opportunity.

Indirect Intermediaries: Third parties engaged and/or compensated by a client, underwriting syndicate, co-investor, counterparty, acquistion target, or another non-firm party involved in a business oppurtunity with the firm provide referrel, introductory or advisory services.
Direct Intermediaries
Indirect Intermediaries
Time To focus:
Learn the Red
Flags
Some of the common red flags for charitable contributions include:
Does not have defined role and will not provide any services in the transaction, but participates inor facilities the firms business discussions.
Is introduced or recommended by a public official or government entity in connection with a transaction
Provides as invoice that appears falsified or with inflated amounts, or duplicative or vague descriptions of services
Refuses to include the firm's standard anti-bribery provisions into the contract covering the interediary arrangement
is located and/or operating in a high risk jurisdiction.

Politically Exposed Person(PEP) 'Politically Exposed Person(PEP)' is an individual who is or has been entrusted with a prominent public function. See the Firmwise Policy on intermediaries/Finders for the full definition.
Requests payments to or retention of a public official or a politically exposed person of their immediate family members or close associates
is located and/ or operating in a high-risk jurisdiction (Review to advance).
Will receive unusually high fees or other compensation/benefits or appears unqualified for the services being provided
For a full list of red flags, including those related to transactions, review the firmwide policy on Intermediaries/Finders.

The business opportunity relates to a data centre.

text.default: That's Incorrect. Red flags for this situation are that the business opportunity is located in the UAE, a higher risk jurisdiction. A third party facilitated an introduction to a government official, and the transaction requires government approval, which creates an opportunity for a bribe. The third party being a former Goldman Sachs and known to have improper conduct history is also a red flag. The deal team should escalate the former MD as a potential intermediary to the anti-bribery group. A policy defines intermediaries to include third parties, family, or informally engaged even if not compensated to introduce a business opportunity.

Bribery Risk: Vendors and Other Third Parties
Did You Know....
FCC Anti-Bribery and Anti-Corruption Training 2024
the firm currently has over 9,000 unique active vendors and approximately 2,300 of our people serving as Vendor Relationship Owners(VROs)
At the Core
What do you need to know about the bribery and corruption risks presented by vendors?
Select the arrow button to find out more.
Your Responsibilities
You should know if your vendor is considered high-risk from a bribery and corruption perspective! You must receive pre approval from the anti bribery group befor engaging any high risk vendors.
All VROs are responsible for onboarding their vendors to the know your third party system prior to commencing work and should have oversight of vendor conduct all times.
Time To focus:
Learn the Red
Flags
Some of the common red flags are when the vendor or other third party:
Is managed, owned or controlled by public officials
Provides entertainment to public officials.
Charges usually high or unexplained fees
Has received negative media or whistleblowing allegations that suggest fraud, bribery or other financial risks
is recommended to the firm by public official or government entity
Put it into Practice

The firm is entering into a joint venture with a real estate firm, which plans to hire a vendor located in japan to oversee the construction of office space. This vendor is known to have many local connections and will be reponsible to obtaining approvals and permits from local government authorities for this construction, on behalf of the joint venture. The firm agreed on a contract for US$200,000 all inclusive.However , when the first invoice arrives ,it is for US$400,000 with no explanation or supporting documentation. The firm joint venture partner selcted the vendor based on a recommendation from a local politician rather than a competitive standard vendor bidding process.
Which of the following are red flags for bribery and corruption risk in this situation? Remember to read the options carefully.There may be more than one correct answer.
The vendor changed an uncertainity high free explanation or documentation.

payload.value: The vendor changed an uncertainity high free explanation or documentation.

payload.value: The vendor is located in a low-risk jurisdiction

text.default: The vendor was referred by a local politician.

payload.value: The vendor was referred by a local politician.

text.default: That's Incorrect. Red flags for this situation where the vendor charge and unusually high fee which combined with the fact that vendor was recommended by a local politician and original subject to a competitive standard when the bidding process means that there is a possibility of that this could be a corrupt payment Japan is the lowest jurisdiction and therefore is not traded our this role does not potential to every risk.

Bribery Risk: Gifts, Travel and Entertainment
Think about it...

offering gifts, travel and entertainment is often helpful in strengthening business relationships, but they must be appropriate relationships, but they must be appropriate and never lavish or excessive.

Lavish or excessive gifts, travel and entertainment may improperly influence the recipient's business judgement or have the appearance that the firm is trying to obtain or retain business in exchange of these benefits, which violates anti-bribery and anti-corruption laws and raises bribey and corruptuon risk to the firm. Conversely, you should not accept gifts,travels or entertainment that are lavish or so frequest they may raise a question of impropriety.Just you take time and care when purchasing gifts for those close to you or booking personal travel, you should pay close attention to your busiess offerings , recipients and expenses.
At the Core
What do you wanted to know more about gifts, travel and entertainment? Follow these Do's and Don'ts.

Restricted Recipients are public officials, employees of exchange and other self regulatory organizations, examiners, credit rating agencies and National Statistical Rating organizations and ERISA fiduciaries.

Submit pre-approval requests in concur for: 1). All gifts (prior to purchase) to clients or other third parties, including Restricted Recipients( Review to advance). 2). All travel and entertainment of resctricted recipients regardless of the cost
Offer promise or authorize gifts,travel and entertainment to improperly influence govt or regulatory action, to obtain or maintain business or an improper business advantage.
All travel and entertainment to all other clients or third parties that you know in advance or expect will exeed US$250 per person
Donation solicitation received from, or recipient charity located in a jurisdiction known to be high-risk for bribery and corruption.

Accurately report and record the total value of all gifts , travel and entertainment in concur in a timely manner, even if part or all the expense is paid with personal funds and you are not seeking reimbursement.
Accept gifts from the third parties with which firm ihas a business relationship withpout approval via the firms receipt of GCE Tool.
Only request reinbursement for valid business expenses. you are expected to carefully review your own expenses, even if the reports are prepared by others on your behalf
Any travel or entertainment greater than US$250 must be submitted through the tool for additional review.
Time To focus:
Learn the Red
Flags
Some of the common red flags for gifts, travel and entertainment are:
Excessive entertainment of a single individual who is a key client decision-maker
Entertaining a Restricted Recipient without seeking pre-approval
Charging inappropriate personal expenses to client projects.
Inviting a prospective client to a potentially lavish event ahead of a deal pitch.
Topping off or falling to report the full value of gift travel and entertainment provided by absorbing the excess amounts from personal funds.
Adding attendees to request for approval to reduce the per-person cost
Review the core principles of the firmwide policy on gifts travel for more details.
Put it into Practice

Joe from GBM Private has been hoping to obtain the business of a sovreign wealth fund and has been pitching ideas to its CEO. The sovereign wealth fund will make decision in the following week on which investment bank to engage as a advisor . Joe knows that the CEO enjoys fine dinning, and he manages to secure the last minute left at a exclusive michelin started restaurant without seeking pre approval.The ceo was available at evening and accepted joe's invite when it was time to submit hits expensive report joe was worried that the expenses would be rejected as the final bill amount came to total of GBP2,000 for two people.Joe was proceede to include multiple goldman sachs attendees such that the person per a,ount was reduced to GBP200 per person.
Which of the following are red flags for bribery and corruption risk in this situation?
Joe did not seek pre-approval to entertain the client, who works for a sovereign welath fund and would be a restricted recipient.

Bribery Risk: Political and Charitable Contributions
Think about it...

Many of our people are passionate about their political and charitable affiliations.Unfortunately, under certain circumstances these activities can present elevated bribery and corruption risks, or atleast raise appearance issues.

Keep in mind that rules with respect to the political activities are complex and vary by jurisdiction with severe penalities for violations. Similarly, charitable contributions,including to bona fide charities, must never be made if the intent or effect is to inappropriately influence the business judgement of any person, including a public official, client,potential,client, or government action. So.if you are unsure-ask questions and seek guidance from compliance.
At the Core
What do you wanted to know more about intermediaries?
Select each button to learn more.
never make or solicit of political or charitable contribution or engage in political or charitable activity to improve the influence are obtained or retained business or a business advantage

Seek  pre approval certain business related charitable contributions such as those related to public officials or government entities high risk jurisdictions of pending from routine business must be pre-approved by the anti group the firm also requires pre approval before our people make political contributions or otherwise engaged in political activity
even contributions to Bonafide charities may create the appearance of potential bribery is linked to form business or a government action
Never Solicit Contributions for Improper Purposes
Be aware of Appearances
Seek-Pre-Approval

Flags
Some of the common red flags for charitable contributions include:
A public official requesting or otherwise associated with a contribution.
Donation solicitation received from, or recipient charity located in a jurisdiction known to be high-risk for bribery and corruption.
Communication that suggest the award or contracting of business is dependent on making a contribution
The firm has pending business with the client requesting contribution
A lack of transparency around the bank account for the charitable recipient.
Review the Policy on charitable contributions for a full list of red flags.
Put it into Practice

A PMD in wealth Management invites you to attend the annual gala for non-profit organization which he supports.The PMD mentions that has purchased a table for the gala at the request of a prospective client who is also in a leadership position with the non-profit.It is common for wealthy individuals to have leadership posiitons at non-profits and for the firm to support worthy causes.Later that day, you are copied on a e-profits and for the firm to support worthy causes. Later that day,Your are copied on a e-mail where the prospective client indicates that they anticipate awarding Goldman Sachs with an upcoming transaction if the firm purchases another table at the event.

Similarly, charitable contributions,including to bona fide charities, must never be made if the intent or effect is to inappropriately influence the business judgement of any person, including a public official, client,potential,client, or government action. So.if you are unsure-ask questions and seek guidance from compliance.
At the Core
What do you wanted to know more about intermediaries?
Select each button to learn more.
never make or solicit of political or charitable contribution or engage in political or charitable activity to improve the influence are obtained or retained business or a business advantage

Seek  pre approval certain business related charitable contributions such as those related to public officials or government entities high risk jurisdictions of pending from routine business must be pre-approved by the anti group the firm also requires pre approval before our people make political contributions or otherwise engaged in political activity
even contributions to Bonafide charities may create the appearance of potential bribery is linked to form business or a government action
Never Solicit Contributions for Improper Purposes
Be aware of Appearances
Seek-Pre-Approval
Time To focus:
Learn the Red
Flags
Some of the common red flags for charitable contributions include:
A public official requesting or otherwise associated with a contribution.
Donation solicitation received from, or recipient charity located in a jurisdiction known to be high-risk for bribery and corruption.
Communication that suggest the award or contracting of business is dependent on making a contribution
The firm has pending business with the client requesting contribution
A lack of transparency around the bank account for the charitable recipient.
Review the Policy on charitable contributions for a full list of red flags.
Put it into Practice

A PMD in wealth Management invites you to attend the annual gala for non-profit organization which he supports.The PMD mentions that has purchased a table for the gala at the request of a prospective client who is also in a leadership position with the non-profit.It is common for wealthy individuals to have leadership posiitons at non-profits and for the firm to support worthy causes.Later that day, you are copied on a e-profits and for the firm to support worthy causes. Later that day,Your are copied on a e-mail where the prospective client indicates that they anticipate awarding Goldman Sachs with an upcoming transaction if the firm purchases another table at the event.
Which of the following are red flags for bribery and corruption risk in this situation?
The prospective client has a leadership position with the non-profit.

payload.value: The prospective client has a leadership position with the non-profit.

text.default: The prospective client indicates that business will be awarded only if another table is purchased.

payload.value: The prospective client indicates that business will be awarded only if another table is purchased.

text.default: The PMD supports the non-profit organization.

payload.value: The PMD supports the non-profit organization.

text.default: That's Incorrect. Red flags for this situation are that the business opportunity is located in the UAE, a higher risk jurisdiction. A third party facilitated an introduction to a government official, and the transaction requires government approval, which creates an opportunity for a bribe. The third party being a former Goldman Sachs and known to have improper conduct history is also a red flag. The deal team should escalate the former MD as a potential intermediary to the anti-bribery group. A policy defines intermediaries to include third parties, family, or informally engaged even if not compensated to introduce a business opportunity.
